post_text: Tomorrow is the big day! We are excited to welcome FNESU students back to school. Please watch out for school busses on the road. If you see lights flashing, use caution! Our new protocols may take us a little longer than normal. Thank you for your understanding.
shared_text:
VTrans
September 7 at 4:30 PM ·

As schools open up and children are back on the road, keep in mind that school bus stops and parent drop-offs will take more time than we’re used to. That means more congestion in front of schools, the potential for more vehicles stopped on the road, and more kids and adults near traffic. If you are driving, remember these simple rules:

• Yellow flashing lights on a school bus mean slow down — don’t speed up — because the bus is preparing to stop. There are likely students waiting to get on the bus or parents waiting nearby to pick up children.
• Red flashing lights mean stop — and wait at least 20 feet behind the bus — because children are getting on or off the school bus. Stay stopped until the red lights stop flashing, the extended stop-arm is withdrawn, and the bus begins moving.
• Even when lights aren’t flashing, watch for children, particularly in the morning or mid-afternoon, around school arrival and dismissal times. Be alert as you back out of a driveway, or drive through a neighborhood, school zone, or bus stop.

shared_text:
Child’s Play Early Learning
May 20 at 11:15 AM ·

Here is a fun activity that will get kids counting, practicing number recognition, fine motor skills, and more using bean seeds and disposable pots. If you don’t have mini pots, use small disposable bathroom cups instead. If you don’t have beans, us can use small rocks, stones, twigs, dandelion heads, goldfish crackers, etc.
How to play:
Roll the dice
Use the tweezers to pick up the beans one by one
You can either put one bean in each pot as you count, or you can put all the beans in the same pot of the number you rolled. (So if you rolled a 6, all the beans would go into the #6 pot).

Adding the tweezers is totally optional. Children will still get tons of small motor pincher grasp practice just by picking up the bean or object you use!

You can either put one bean in each pot as you count, or you can put all the beans in the same pot of the number you rolled. (So if you rolled a 6, all the beans would go into the #6 pot).

Adding the tweezers is totally optional. Children will still get tons of small motor pincher grasp practice just by picking up the bean or object you use!

Enosburg Middle School
February 11 at 12:07 PM ·

EFMS students got to experience an AWESOME interactive presentation with Holly Morin, a marine biologist and researcher who recently went on TWO scientific expeditions to the Arctic and Antarctic (both the north and south poles)!

Holly shared her experiences studying creatures in the deep sea using robotics, studying marine mammals like whales, otters, polar bears, and seals, and shared what the life of a scientist is like on a research trip. She also talked about the path she took that led her to her current career, and how it takes MANY types of jobs (artists, cooks, engineers, mechanics, pilots, and video production crews, to name a few) to pull off an arctic expedition on a ship!

Kids asked awesome questions and learned a lot about geography, oceanography, and marine biology. It was a great experience! Thank you, Holly, for visiting our school!

post_text: Congratulations to Montgomery Elementary School for being one of two Vermont schools to receive a $15,000 technology grant through a partnership with the Vermont Lottery and the Vermont Agency of Education! The focus of the grant is to further technology education programs in schools and support the concept of Makerspaces. With funds from this grant, students at MES will research the nature found on the nature trail between the school grounds and the Montgomery Rec Center and construct panels with buttons that narrate the information, provided bird calls, etc. The construction of the panels will require students to research, write, draw, construct, and build circuits. Thank you Nicole Lacharite, Danielle Berg, Kristina Bowen, and Lara Morales for your effort with proposing and writing this grant. The students at MES will certainly gain technology information and knowledge that will carry with them for many years to come!

As there appears to be some misinformation circulating claiming that this will be the last group of NHS inductees at EFHS, we wish to clarify that this is absolutely not the case. The four NHS tenets of Service, Leadership, Character, and Scholarship will always be fostered and grown here at EFHS, and the National Honor Society will continue to play a role in that growth. We encourage any parent or community member who has questions about structures such as NHS in a proficiency-based system to reach out to our school. We appreciate the opportunity to help clarify your questions and receive your feedback as we grow to support the sort of student success that was on display last night.
Once again, congratulations to the 2018 NHS inductees!
